body: This issue has been closed due to lack of activity. If you think that is incorrect, or the issue requires additional review, you can revive the issue at any time.

It turns out to be an issue with Jackson release higher than 2.7 where if there is a defaultImpl, in JsonTypeInfo tag. I am able to get past this with Jackson 2.6.7 which is what druid 0.15 uses but any version higher than 2.7 will break the druid indexer when using Spark. Ref https://github.com/FasterXML/jackson-databind/issues/1565
Prev. discussion about AutoValue: #4125
@jihoonson when find and fix bugs like this please create issues like #8330.
try to use exit command after "nohup bin/start-micro-quickstart &"

@leventov This is a good idea :+1: Alternatively, we can also install the LGTM robot directly in the project. It automatically performs code reviews for each Pull Request to prevent unintentional bringing these issues to the project. For example, the [asdf2014/algorithm](https://github.com/asdf2014/algorithm) project.

Pull Request:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8108788/63250514-68c6ef80-c29e-11e9-9531-54b5c2fc94b4.png)
Shields:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8108788/63250564-872ceb00-c29e-11e9-9c87-27007911bcf9.png)

BTW there is a relatively simple (though hacky) workaround of ByteBuffer's 2GB limitation without implementing #3892 in full: we can manage a single continuous block of off-heap memory as `Memory` object and convert slices of it to `ByteBuffer` for further use in Druid's core query processing logic using the [`unsafeByteBufferView()`](https://datasketches.github.io/api/memory/snapshot/apidocs/org/apache/datasketches/memory/Memory.html#unsafeByteBufferView-long-int-) method.
+1 on this issue, is there any ETA or anymore information about this topic ? Thanks a lot.
@asdf2014 this is managed on the ApacheInfra level and could be prohibited because they have a white list of integrations. See https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/INFRA-15096.
If someone who knows the code wants to work on this, I'd love to help out.
@leventov I see. Thanks a lot.
Hi there! We're dealing with the same issue. Did you ever find a solution?

@mincong-h that would be wonderful. Looks like the default for LineWrappingIndentation is ok, but forceStrictCondition should be "true".

@leventov for this particular case, I would rather not open an issue like #8330 until https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/8328 is resolved since #8330 could be not necessary depending on how we handle the issue in #8328.

@jihoonson I think it's better to close an issue when it becomes irrelevant than to forget to create it in the first place. As many discussion threads linger, creating a condition in one engineer's brain to create an issue when another issue is resolved in a specific way creates a high probability of forgetting.
seems duplicate of https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/7926

@nicopadu thanks for pointing the potentially related issue. 

@RestfulBlue it seems the same issue with #7926 to me. Did you turn on `resetOffsetAutomatically` for your supervisor? If so, https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/8305 probably will fix this.

Do you think you can find a way to control style/indentation for subcategories on the sidebar? I think the distinction between 2nd and 3rd levels (and so on) isn't clear enough. 
The only thing I found is subcategory collapse, which should be available on v2 (currently early alpha): https://github.com/facebook/Docusaurus/issues/1352

@yurmix I looked into Docusaurus v2 and it looks like it is not quite ready for prime time use which is why we did not use it here. Totally down to switch to it once it comes out (or at least becomes more stable).

As for the indentation we can play with the CSS a bit to make it more obvious in the meantime - in a subsequent PR, trying to get this merged so we do not have to live in conflict hell.

I just gave it a try. Unfortunately, this issue is more difficult than I expected. **I'm afraid I have to stop here.** Here are the 2 approaches I tried:

IntelliJ IDEA + [IntelliJ Checkstyle Plugin](https://plugins.jetbrains.com/plugin/1065-checkstyle-idea):

- Ensure "Editor > Code Style" is configured with scheme: "Druid Java and Scala style"
- Download plugin from the Marketplace
- Go to "Other Settings" and import `./codestyle/checkstyle.xml` and `./codestyle/checkstyle-suppressions.xml` as Third-Party Checks
- On project view, right click on root module "druid", select "Reformat Code"

Eclipse IDE + [Eclipse Checkstyle Plugin](https://checkstyle.org/eclipse-cs/):

- Ensure "Java > Code Style > Formatter" has profile configured as "druid"
- Download plugin from the Marketplace (drag and drop from webpage to IDE)
- On project view, right click on root module "druid", select "Source > Format"

Both approaches corrects a lot of lines. Eclipse, for example, made 3545 files changed: 76753 insertions(+), 98589 deletions(-). Then, running command `mvn checkstyle:check` still result a lot of errors to be fixed. On one hand, I believe they need to be adjusted manually; on the other hand, some fixes might not be related to `forceStrictCondition=true` (I didn't really dig into this level).

We are using timezones like Etc/GMT-## or Etc/GMT+##, it seems those are not subject to daylight saving changes, so it works around the issue. 
But this is far from ideal, I hope this issue will be addressed...

I read through https://github.com/google/auto/blob/master/value/userguide/index.md and `AutoValue` does sound relatively better considering it generates new classes.
there would be some bunch of annotations needed to make json serde of those objects work,and also probably you need to define constructor with json annotations in the abstract class . anyways, my first impression is that it could be made to work.
there is a warning mentioned,  "Be careful that you don't accidentally pass parameters to the generated constructor in the wrong order. You must ensure that your tests are sufficient to catch any field ordering problem." tells that you still need to carefully unit test or else someone just changing ordering of getters in abstract class could introduce silent bugs.

@adziri @erindru I had the same issue. The problem seems to be that the jars are not found in the class path. 

From the script [run-zk](https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/druid-0.15.1-incubating-rc2/examples/bin/run-zk#L41), 

```
exec java `cat "$CONFDIR"/jvm.config | xargs` \
  -cp "$WHEREAMI/../zk/lib/*:$WHEREAMI/../zk/*:$CONFDIR" \
  org.apache.zookeeper.server.quorum.QuorumPeerMain \
  "$CONFDIR"/zoo.cfg
```

This would expand to something like depending on your environment:
`incubator-druid/examples/bin/../zk/lib/`, so the libraries are expected to be in `incubator-druid/examples/zk`.

But the documentation here is incorrect:

> The startup scripts for the tutorial will expect the contents of the Zookeeper tarball to be located at zk under the apache-druid-0.15.1-incubating package root.

Moving `zk` to `examples/` fixes the issue for me.

I think we could either:
- update the documentation to reflect the correct directory for zk
- change the run scripts to use the package root directory

If you think that's incorrect or this pull request should instead be reviewed, please simply write any comment. Even if closed, you can still revive the PR at any time or discuss it on the dev@druid.apache.org list. Thank you for your contributions.
Thanks for letting me know! Are you able to re-open this issue in that case?

Any thoughts about this? Is there a way to handle it?

We have increased the value of `maxZnodeBytes` to `32 MB` but the system became unstable (slow startup; `/opt/zookeeper/current/transactions/version-2/` directory doubled in size) and we had to rollback the change.

Thank you!

@fjy @clintropolis @surekhasaharan thanks for the review!

Note that the coveralls check shows decreased coverage as the web-console coverage was added and unfortunately has lower coverage (https://coveralls.io/jobs/52308700) than the java code, thereby decreasing the overall coverage.
@vogievetsky FYI, this PR adds web-console to coveralls.

I have some ideas for this and the basic approach is to use travis to [launch the code inspections from the command line](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/command-line-code-inspector.html) inside an intellij docker image. Some rough prototyping on my laptop shows the analysis completes in about 30 minutes for warnings and errors or about 20 minutes just errors. The drawback is that it likely won't have the nice TeamCity UI to browse the inspection report and view the delta, but it'll definitely be enough to detect if new errors are added and to print information about those errors.

thanks , it might be good enough as long as all necessary info is present in the output .

really appreciate all your contributions towards making build improvements.
